content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the payoff structure, it seems like this is a mixed-strategy game where neither pure strategy (always picking the same move) is optimal. In such games, it's often beneficial to randomly select moves to maximize expected payoff.

However, in a practical sense, as a human player in 75 rounds of this game, I would lean towards a more R-dominant strategy due to the significant advantage (45$ versus 20$) when both players pick R. This is a relatively large difference considering each round has only a 20$ variance for picking B instead of R.

At the same time, it's important not to completely ignore the 40$ gain for choosing B when the opponent picks R (which happens in half the rounds). If I were to randomly select R or B, I would slightly favor R due to its higher potential payoff but maintain a certain level of randomness to minimize predictability.

With that said, as a human player, I would choose R more often than B, but not always. My choice, given my reasoning, would be: {R}

It's worth noting that if I were a computer algorithm making decisions based on maximizing expected value, the optimal mixed strategy would involve choosing R approximately 58.7% of the time and B approximately 41.3% of the time. This is to maintain an unpredictable pattern while still favoring the R move due to its higher payoff when both players pick it.

In this case, as a human player, I may not be able or willing to maintain such an exact ratio in real-time decisions, but I would try to skew my choices towards R more often than B based on the reasoning provided above.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would choose R again. My reasoning is based on the fact that my initial choice of R led to a higher payoff (45$) compared to choosing B (20$). While there is a possibility that my opponent might switch strategies and pick B in the next round, I still believe that R offers a greater potential payoff when both players pick it.

If my opponent sticks with their choice of R in the next round, we will both receive another 45$ each. If not, I may face a lower payoff if they choose B (20$), but I would maintain the expectation that I should lean towards choosing R more often due to its higher potential reward.

In summary, in this specific instance, I chose R in the first round and will continue to choose R in the next round. My choice: {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I was unlucky that my opponent picked B while I picked R in the previous round. As a result, I got a payout of 0$ and my opponent received 40$.

For the next round, I would adjust my strategy slightly to account for the possibility of my opponent switching strategies based on their understanding of my past choices. In particular, I might lean more towards choosing B in the following round as retaliation for my opponent's choice in the previous round.

However, it is important not to overreact and maintain some level of randomness to avoid being too predictable. Given that the payoff difference between R and B is substantial when both players pick their respective moves (45$ vs 20$), I would still want to skew my choices towards R more often than B in the long run.

In this specific instance, I chose B for the next round. My choice: {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

For the next round, I would consider my past choices (picking B) and my opponent's reaction (choosing R) to make an informed decision about my strategy going forward. In this case, it seems that my initial choice of B elicited a response from my opponent to choose R. To avoid being too predictable and possibly encourage my opponent to switch their strategy, I might lean more towards choosing R in the next round.

However, it is crucial not to overreact and maintain some level of randomness to keep my opponent guessing. Given that the payoff difference between R and B is substantial when both players pick their respective moves (45$ vs 20$), I would still want to skew my choices towards R more often than B in the long run, as it offers a higher potential reward.

However, as a rational player, I should consider the long-term strategy and not be overly influenced by short-term gains or losses. In this game, there is no information about my opponent's past choices, so it is impossible to predict their future behavior with certainty. To avoid being too predictable, I would maintain some level of randomness in my choices between R and B.
